author: Duq
title: It's a jeep, but is it a Jeep?
review:
Lego's Technic licensing trend continues. This time a mid-sized off-roader gets a Jeep badge. Does it live up to that badge? Let's find out.

Parts

Let's start with parts, 665 of them. Pins and 2L and 3L axles make up a whopping 47% of that! So what else will you find in the box? A few of the new-this-year 3x7 panels (3 yellow and a black), the tiny 2x3 panels (3 yellow), two turntables for the suspension and a few non-Technic parts, mainly for lights. What will you not find? Gears! Well... there are 2, a 12T and a 16T.

There are a few printed beams for the trademarked Jeep grille, and a sheet with 14 stickers.

Building

Parts come in two sets of bags but the split seems rather arbitrary; at the end of bag 1 you have the chassis and part of the body completed. The core you build at the start is as dense and compact as I've come across. By step 20 you've used 50 parts and the model is no more than 2 inches in any direction.

The build is not challenging if you've built Technic before. Front and rear suspension use the same concept of a pendulum axle. A small turntable is used as the pivot, allowing the steering axle to go through. A the back two springs hold the car level. A clever and interesting technique, but not difficult to build.

Looks

When you're finished you have a nice looking Technic off-road car. This one however is branded as 'Jeep'. At the end of the instruction book are a few pictures of the real Jeep Rubicon and to me they mainly highlight how little the set looks like the prototype. Most of the proportions are wrong; the roof too low, the grille too flat, the wheel arches too big. The black frame at the back for the soft-top should be yellow, the dark grey angles on the bumpers should be black.

There's a bit of interior, with a sticker for the dashboard, and even stickers that go on the inside of the angled panels so the seats have the right Jeep stitching. But then there's also the axle for the hand-of-god steering through the cabin. 

The doors have no top half, and strangely seem to be missing another beam at the bottom, leaving a strange gap.

Did I mention it's small? It's got some 85 parts more than the Corvette but it's two inches shorter.

Playing

It's got a good few play features for a small set; steering, suspension, a winch, opening doors and bonnet (even if there isn't much to see under the bonnet). The hand-of-god steering (the knob is one of the two gears in the set) is at an angle, rather than vertical like on most Technic sets. Given the amount of sideways pushing to activate the suspension I'm not sure that's the best choice.

Speaking of suspension. The rear suspension is very limited in its travel. I wasn't sure why, so removed the two yellow crankshaft pieces and sure enough, the suspension travel improved. Unfortunately the front couldn't keep up and now the front wheels would jam in their arches when you steer and compress the suspension.

Speaking of steering... The mechanism is simple and sort of effective, but it also has a tiny steering angle, giving the little Jeep the turning circle of Titanic. This has been a Technic problem for decades.

The final play feature is the winch in the front bumper and it's as simple as they come. The second gear in the set is used to winch the cable in an out, using only the friction of a pin to stop it moving, so you can't pull any weight until you're at the end of the string.

Verdict

This is a good-looking fun off-roader. I have no doubt children will have fun playing with it.

The branding however suggests that it's (also) aiming at adults and here it just falls short; the looks are not close enough and the limited steering and suspension are disappointing.

Building the suspension is interesting but there's just something wrong about a Technic set without gears.

I wonder why LEGO decided to do this set as a licensed set. Why not do a licensed Creator Expert set for adults that looks the part, and have a cheaper (no license, no printed parts) generic off-roader as a Technic play set?

Is it value for money? Purely on price per part it's not as good as its similar sized licensed cousins the Senna and the Corvette but ultimately I think it depends on what you're looking for.

author: DoonsterBuildsLego
title: Solid little vehicle that works well with the others at this scale
review:
There is nothing complex about the building process it is also nicely sequenced: no fiddly sections and everything flows nicely. The build is split into 2 sections with numbered bags, starting with the main chassis & then building the bodywork and accessories finishing with the wheels.

There is quite a nice selection of parts, a few system elements to add aesthetic functions and some nice functional bits underneath. Plus there are a few new elements, although I don't think it's enough to warrant buying purely as a parts pack. The main distinguishing feature of the Jeep Wrangler - its radiator grille - is printed, th rest comes as stickers. I don't feel the stickers are really necessary and haven't applied them. Those grille prints are across several parts, and they can be printed a little off - it took me a little while to arrange them in such a way to minimise the effects of the printing offsets. My model doesn't look as obviously out of line as other pictures I've seen.

The suspension mechanism is the main play feature here and it is nicely executed. The rear suspension would have benefited, I think, from a swing arm arrangement to allow both springs to compress together. As it is, both axles work on a rocker arrangement. The steering doesn't offer a very tight turning circle - I think it can be modified to improve that a little as there is sufficient space for the wheels to turn further.

I also very much like that the size is compatible with 42098 Car Transporter so that I can store/display all the vehicles together.

It's a little disappointing that there is no working engine, but the suspension and steering mechanisms largely preclude including one without major modifications.

Overall, then, I think this is a nice model to fit with the line of similarly sized vehicles and is pretty good value for money, even at full price.

author: chefkaspa
title: Target audience?
review:
Motivation?

I decided that I wouldn't buy the set soon. I am no big fan of technic cars and this one offers few functions:
- steering
- pendular suspension on front and rear axle
plus:
- opening doors
- foldable bench in rear
- winch

This appears to be poor compared with other recent cars of the technic line (#42075, #42093, blue car, #42123): These all have transmission including differential and (fake) engine setup.

This set would be of interest because it is the one with most new technic parts:

  • tractor tyres (5x)
  • 3x7 panels (two colours)
  • 2x3 panel
  • 2x1 cross block (new in yellow)

Instead, I bought the new parts form Lego shop and ordered all available colours.
Therefore, my version of the Jeep was built using the dark azur variant.

According to Brickset database, the box size is the same as 42107, 42106, 42094, 42079, 42062).

Assembly

Parts were taken from my spares and instruction downloaded from Lego.com using the link provided by Brickset.

The interior of the car is assembled from a plethora of differently coloured parts. This is different from the Volvo truck (#42114) that is much more complicated.

For several units I thought that these are designed overly complicated and much more solid than required:
- central piece that gets constructed first
- rear axle is a 5M 'high' stack of beams and connectors
- block between driver cabin and 'motor' area

The final set is of similar size than 42075 First Responder.

Functions

I am disappointed by the models main functions:

1. Steering angle is abysmal. Diameter of turning circle is > 100 cm, about 25 cm less than for the concrete mixer truck. There must be a better setup of steered axle than this:

The 7M beam poses limit to the steering angle.

2. Rear axle suspension. In contrast to the front axle the rear has two (hard) springs. These are attached to a lever so that the spring only gets compressed if the axle is moving towards the chassis. At first, you will notice a large way od travel. However, this gets restricted to (ca.) 1/2M when the trunk is added. I assume that is still sufficient for playing.
This restriction is similarly applied to the front axle.

3. Winch - This is a very basic setup relying solely on the af friction pin 'brake'. It is "controlled" by a 16-teeth gear wheel.

Rating

My conclusion: This set could be a nice parts pack.
From pictures the yellow = original version would be nice as a display set.
However, I am very disappointed by the technical features.


(There are no 3M beams respectively half liftarms in Dark Azur. Therefore, I built front grille and doors in bright blue.)

author: Karidian
title: Fun Easy Build!
review: Bought this kit thinking it would be fun to build and display.   I was not let down.   I finish the build in one day, breaking in between bags labelled 1 and 2.   Instructions very straight forward, but I do miss the red outline for where to add the parts in each step.  This time I used the PDF instruction manual displayed on a large monitor on my work area.  This method was a huge improvement over dealing with the large manual and shuffling it around on the desk as i had done with my previous builds.  For the winch rope I sealed the knots with clear fingernail polish so the knots wouldn't unravel.  Much simpler build than my other car builds, and it was a real treat to see it coming together.   Smaller in scale, but a really nice size to easily display.   Thinking of trying some photos outside in the dirt with this one just for fun.   Really enjoyed building the Wrangler and wish there were more kits like this one.  Would be a great first build for a new builder.

author: GrandInqusitor
title: After 15 or more years without lego
review:
So I started to look out for new hobby to spend time in the evenings (instead of TV) and I stumbled across some lego commercial and thought cool, let's see what other products they offer. I scanned different sites and the smaller lego products (City, System) bit too easy, until I stumbled across Technic products. I did not want to go in big with my first set. After all maybe I will not enjoy the progress.

 

Building/Parts

So yesterday I built this, and it took me about 4.5 hours with few pauses included (Dinner etc) Probably 3+h of build time. The build is actually quite simple there are not many systems in it, but it gets a lot done with easy building. (Simple suspension and steering). But being away this long this set gave me some insight how building is changed since last time I touched lego.

 

Aesthetics

It looks pretty nice in completed state. My only thought would be that front lights could have been a bit more inside the front grill but that maybe would have left some gap in the front. I don't know what parts lego has nowadays to be able to achieve this.

 

Playability

Turning circle is awful, and the winch is more of a display piece. I probably won't play with it much though :)

 

Conclusion

This set reintroduced me to Lego and I have already ordered next sets to build, with bit more difficulty this time. All in all probably some seasoned technic lovers don't find this set all that interesting, but it's a good starter set. I would rate it 4 of 5.
